channel.title: BBC News - Business

item.title: Government strikes deal to kickstart CO2 production
item.description: It comes after one industry group warned shoppers could start noticing gaps on shelves within days.

item.title: Gas price crisis: Government poised to step in, says Kwarteng
item.description: The government is likely to help big gas providers forced to take customers from failed firms.

item.title: Staff to gain day one right to request flexible working
item.description: Under government proposals, all employees will be given the right to request flexible working.

item.title: Inflation to remain higher for two years, warns OECD
item.description: The UK is expected to have inflation of 3% at the end of 2022, the highest rate of the advanced economies.

item.title: National Express in talks to buy transport rival Stagecoach
item.description: The move comes after both bus firms were hit hard by falling passenger numbers during the pandemic.

item.title: Government borrowing higher than expected in August
item.description: Borrowing was lower than a year earlier, but was still the second-highest on record for August.

item.title: Evergrande: Asia stocks mixed as investors weigh China concerns
item.description: The Chinese property giant is facing a debt crisis, triggering fears of contagion in global markets.

item.title: Pimlico Plumbers sold to US firm Neighborly
item.description: The deal will see founder Charlie Mullins offload his 90% stake in the group.

item.title: What is the energy price cap and what if my supplier goes bust?
item.description: Gas prices have soared by 250% since January, but what does that mean for household bills?

item.title: Covid: US opens up to fully vaccinated travellers
item.description: The US rolls back international travel restrictions, answering a major demand from allies.

item.title: Gas crisis: No chance lights will go out, says government
item.description: Business secretary Kwasi Kwarteng says the UK has "more than sufficient capacity" amid gas price spike.

item.title: Gas crisis: Pig farmers fear they may have to cull animals
item.description: A shortage of carbon dioxide used to stun pigs at abattoirs means a backlog of animals is growing.

item.title: Gas prices: 'I'm just watching the meter go up'
item.description: Customers caught in the middle of the energy price crisis face higher bills but are told not to panic.

item.title: Electricity energy costs damaging sector, says UK Steel
item.description: Some firms are being forced to temporarily pause production when the price goes "through the roof".

item.title: Christmas toy price rises and stock shortages warning
item.description: One toy firm says rising shipping costs and HGV driver shortages are making for "a perfect storm".

item.title: Timber shortage: Port of King's Lynn sees imports double in a year
item.description: A port sees timber imports double in the past year as people take on construction and home projects.

item.title: UK energy company seeks funds to stay afloat
item.description: Bulb, the UK's sixth largest energy provider, is seeking funds due to price rises in wholesale gas.

item.title: Gas price rise: US boss holds crisis gas talks with UK
item.description: Meat producers and supermarkets fear a shortage of CO2 will hit the availability of fresh produce.

item.title: Can apps manage our chronic health conditions?
item.description: A Swedish tech firm has created an app to help alleviate people's joint pain.

item.title: 'Looking back, it was an amazing thing I did'
item.description: Meet the founder on a 10-year mission to disrupt Japan's rigid work culture.

item.title: Gen Z battles to bring back unions, one Starbucks at a time
item.description: Younger Americans are reviving US labour activism amid stagnant wages and Covid hardship.

item.title: Why taking up an instrument has struck a chord for so many
item.description: The pandemic led to around 1m UK adults learning an instrument and many taking music lessons.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'You can run a business and have a baby'
item.description: Planning for a maternity leave when you're the boss of a fast-growing company.

item.title: Why even giant ships can't solve the shipping crisis
item.description: A shortage of vessels is hampering global trade and may lead to empty shelves before Christmas.

item.title: Amazon's Cape Town base: The battle to save South African culture
item.description: Some indigenous groups say the planned office in Cape Town is on culturally important land.

item.title: The pressures - and rewards - of being an influencer
item.description: Running your own popular YouTube channel can be lucrative, but it comes with downsides.

item.title: The epicentre of Britain's pandemic house price boom
item.description: House prices have surged in many parts of the UK - and in one district they have risen by 29% in a year.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: Women's state pension: 'It is like you've lived one big lie'
item.description: How women born in the 1950s had their retirement plans upended by state pension age changes.

item.title: How a monkey launched the pop-it toy craze
item.description: Why it took a TikTok primate to turn a forty-year-old idea into a global hit

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: CEO Secrets: The bra boss busting stereotypes
item.description: Leanne Cahill, CEO of Bravissimo, shares her journey from shop floor to boardroom in retail.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.
